review_title: Excellent Department with Room for Improvement
job_title: Assistant to Stacks Maintenance Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros: I worked as a student assistant at the University of New Orleans's Earl K. Long Library for about three years. My supervisor was Janet C. Levkowicz, a learned, witty, and humorous Jewish woman who has worked as the library's Stacks Coordinator for over 25 years. - Great staff of dedicated, knowledgable people; - Stable, safe, quiet work environment; - Free access to university-hosted occasional lunch engagements; - Flexible working schedule; - Sensible routines, comfortable work; - Wide range of library-related experience.
cons: - Student workers are often stuck with the busywork of other departments in the same building; - Rare but memorable encounters with unprofessional staff; - Strange recurrences of periodical/book theft or destruction - Library stacks severely outdated in certain categories, though the material there is often hard to find even in other university libraries (so your mileage may vary); - Unfortunate lack of funding from the higher-ups to support access to online journals/print publications (not the building's issue specifically, but it shows upon investigation) - Bizarre construction renewal projects begun apparently to aid students but which honestly are distracting -- see below

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros:
- Generous leave time, defined benefit pension
- Flexible work hours
cons:
- Policies/procedures are informal and poorly communicated.

- Little-to-no management or direction for most administrative offices. 

- Extra/supplemental pay regularly denied even when employees must take on additional responsibilities well outside the realm of core role.

- Performance evaluation process is extremely vague and unfair. Senior management does not monitor office/employee performance or set expectations/goals. 

- Management's actions often inconsistent with official policies and university “core values.”

- Compensation decisions dominated by administration.

job_title: Biochemistry Theoretical and Computational Drug Design Researcher in New Orleans, LA
pros: Working as a College Tutor, Chemistry Lab TA, recitation lecturer, and also as a drug design researcher gave me the pleasure of being responsible for many tasks which had a direct affect on students and faculty. I am blessed from these several years working with experience in coming up with a lecture for the one hour recitation review, guiding a classroom of students through a three hour experiment once a week, and also, for attending many meetings that integrated staff, graduate students, and the faculty leaders. My job as a researcher was very demanding; but, I cannot say it was anything less than joyful and successful. I lookforward to expanding my college experiences and work ethic into a workplace which is just as passionate.
cons: It was long hours; and often we did not succeed on the first or fifth try. But, with effective communication and a positive attitude, we won conferences and published work on pathogen transmittance. I wouldn't consider my work less than a blessing here.

job_title: Graduate Student Worker in New Orleans, LA
pros: UNO is a diverse campus with students from all over the world.  Culturally, it is accepting of all ages and ethnicities.  The environment is perfect for one who enjoys expanding their knowledge and understanding of others.  Also, for the most part, employees are hard-working and dedicated.  They love the University and its students.  They are a pleasure to work with.
cons: The State of Louisiana is one of the worst when it comes to funding education.  UNO, like every state college and university, suffers from staffing cutbacks.  The motto has become "do more with less."  That includes less pay.  Employees haven't received raises in nearly ten years, despite taking on ever-increasing workloads.

review_title: I worked in admin and as an adjunct instructor.
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New Orleans, LA
pros: They paid $3000 per class and with three classes you get access to benefits. At least back then you did.
cons: The university is stressed. Every department, all the time. They are constantly cutting the budget, laying off employees, and cycling through provosts.

review_title: Great People, Horrible Pay for many of us
job_title: Full Time Faculty in New Orleans, LA
pros: Great students, great faculty, pleasant work environment for faculty. For faculty, you generally have a good schedule and no one breathing down your neck and scrutinizing your every move. (At least in my college.) People generally get along well and if you like being left alone, you've got that to the degree you want it.  It's a great place to work if Bobby Jindal doesn't destroy us.
cons: Unless you're tenured or tenure track faculty coming in at market rate, the pay sucks and you will probably NEVER get a raise.  Some of that is due to budget cuts but some is just because they can get away with it.  You'll be told that, in this environment "you should just be happy you have a job."  I've been there for 13 years and would leave if it weren't for the students and great schedule. Also, not fun to drive there if you don't live nearby.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros:

cons:

The mismanagement of budget for many years.
Gym is not free for faculty/staff.
Politics, Red Tape, etc. lead to unproductive, unsuccessful employees.

job_title: Residential Internet in New Orleans, LA

You meet a lot of people and you also get to learn a little about the networking side of things.
cons: Not really any to think of.

review_title: a state university that serves working class people

review_title: Nightmare work experience. Do your research prior to applying. Not a good place to work.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros:
City of New Orleans

Majority of students are focused and determined - usually non traditional student body (military, older, international students, commuters, local).
cons:
UNO is grossly disorganized and quickly losing ground. My work experience there was particularly bad. I suggest looking elsewhere. 

A few examples:

I was blatantly discriminated because of gender at work repeatedly. I reached out to staff members and HR with little to no response. The responses I did get were delayed, belittling and confusing. An incredibly poor system for handling these types of situations. Be careful. 

Also worked 90+ hour weeks including nights and weekends and was not compensated. Zero supervision over my superior who was assigning work above and beyond what the job required. Again reached out with no success. 

The system of check and balances is completely outdated at the University. In my experience there was very little connectivity between departments, coworkers, students and staff. It was disheartening. 

Beyond that the university is slowly falling apart. They have not and likely will not put much money into updating and making necessary changes to resolve major issues. Prior to applying read into Louisiana current budget crisis and stance on funding education.

review_title: Great place to work, but current budget cuts are making things harder.

pros: Diversity of work, great vacation time, ability to enroll for classes tuition free, good retirement options, ability to learn more about your field, accepting and diverse work environment.
cons: Government consistently cutting budget, hiring freezes, salary tends to be lower, arcane and byzantine state laws sometimes make job unnecessarily difficult, sometimes difficult to get training.
